I think that I shall never see  A poem lovely as a tree  (Joyce Kilmer 1886–1918)
Don't look down. Photo from Alexander Gerst's spacewalk this week.
Does this count as a selfie?

These 16-year-old Irish girls won the Google Science Fair. Worth reading what they did.  http://inhabitat.com/16-year-old-irish-girls-win-google-science-fair-2014-with-world-changing-crop-yield-breakthrough/
Ruins on the beach. No apes in sight  but if I see the Statue of Liberty  I'm turning around.
These three people leave Earth tomorrow  including the first female cosmonaut in 17 years.   http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/serova.html
I don’t think this was translated correctly.
We should all try and be at least as prepared for climate change as we are for the zombie apocalypse.
The perfect sunglasses holder.
Star Wars opening credits on a personalized Kraft Dinner box. Worlds collide.
Big as a house. This asteroid was only detected 5 days ago; will zip past Earth on Sunday.  http://www.nasa.gov/jpl/asteroid/small-asteroid-to-safely-pass-close-to-earth-sunday/#.VAfJgPldWSq
This is a cornfield with a familiar-looking maze cut into it. Fun in Thamesville  Ontario.   http://www.imaze.ca/#/location/
Artwork by Cindy Bolivar (I believe)  whom I've never met. Cool!
To all of us born on the 29th of August  especially crewmate Tom Marshburn - what did you do for your birthday? I ran to the lake and back.
At a given moment  this is our air traffic around the world. (from http://planefinder.net/)
The endless ochre dunes of Australia are unmistakable  no matter what spaceship you're in.
A humble Canadian satellite lets us all see Antarctica like never before: https://uwaterloo.ca/news/news/waterloo-makes-public-most-complete-antarctic-map-climate
This woman is the 1st ever to win the highest world honour in mathematics - the Fields Medal. Congratulations Maryam! http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fields_Medal
The photo on the right took 18 000 soldiers in Iowa in 1918. I wonder what the guy in the eye was wearing? http://www.iowanationalguard.com/History/History/Pages/Human-Photos.aspx …
I'm ridiculously pleased with my doormat.
Good morning  sunshine. I was looking through my space photos last night and found this one. Dawn brings renewal.
My Dad turned 80. He's a farmer. This was his birthday cake.
A familiar roar at Cape Canaveral this morning. Congratulations to SpaceX and the Asiasat team. http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2014/08/spacex-falcon-9-v1-1-asiasat-8-launch/
Waking up Googled. Fun to see today's Doodle!   http://www.google.com/doodles/john-venns-180th-birthday

21 000 years ago  the ice over Montreal was 3 kilometers thick  and dwarfed the Sears and CN Towers. The land is still rising back up like a sponge from the great weight of the ice. Conditions changing over time. (http://xkcd.com)
My Dad  Roger Hadfield  flying a B-17 in 1961 and 2014. Different millennium  same smile.
An unexpected taste of Canada here in the United Arab Emirates. Black coffee and a maple donut at 44 deg C.
Take a seat  he said.
45 years ago today these three men inspired the world with their bravery  skill and example; Thanks Mike  Buzz and Neil.
Clouds lit from below  the sunset's pink underbelly.
This was on my lawn this morning. There can only be one possible explanation.
My Dad  Roger Hadfield  is 80. A former B-17 pilot  had his 1st Fort flight in 50 yrs today. Thanks Vintage Wings of Canada!
Good Morning! - from one of the wonders of the world. Sorry you can't also hear the magnificent roar.
Over Parliament with the RCAF Snowbirds. Very proud to fly the flag high today.
For fun this Canada Day  my brother and I set out to make the most Canadian music video ever. How'd we do?   http://youtu.be/zuVsHt3rBnc
Thank-you  Canada  for this national honour. It means so much to me and my family.  http://www.gg.ca/document.aspx?id=15694&lan=eng
Apology from Ottawa Citizen to David Bowie (Official). Honourable.  http://ottawacitizen.com/news/national/apology-to-david-bowie  Our Oddity will be back online soon.
The other side of the Moon  this giant rock  four football fields long  just silently tumbled past us. Glad it missed.
Spaceships - what we've ridden so far. All to scale  plus numbers of flights. Thanks to Space.com
It's June  and still ice in the Great Lakes. That was a cold winter.
Space Station underlining the immense beauty of the universe. Thoughtful Drew Buckley photo.  http://tinyurl.com/nm89sm2

People have been dreaming of this for years. I hope this brilliant  restless inventor can truly make it happen!   http://www.nbcnews.com/science/space/elon-musks-spacex-plans-dragonfly-landing-tests-n111386
Time travel! Same guy  same place  1977 vs 2014. At Fernsehturm/St Mary's in Berlin  pre & post-moustache
Bowie's last day - we had permission for a year  so our Space Oddity video comes down today. One last look: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KaOC9danxNo
It's Mothers' Day! Love to my Mom  and a picture of us together from my Christening  long ago. Call your Mom!
Farley Mowat's writing and choices inspired me. Thank you for a lifetime of passion. Rest in Peace.
Spent a day with one of my childhood TV heroes. Great delight - William Shatner is a thoughtful and interesting man.
People have been living where London now shines for 6500 years or more. Currently choosing night cities for the book.
Good morning  Earth! Announcing a new book  full of unpublished space photos  with notes and comments. Coming in October.
I know it's just a number  but I'm delighted that a million people have watched my TED talk. It was fun to do.  http://www.ted.com/talks/chris_hadfield_what_i_learned_from_going_blind_in_space
Sometimes it's good to look closely at a rule and make sure it makes sense.
Canada's Mounties. Thanks  gentlemen  for taking such good care of me  Prince George  and everyone else. Class.
This young astronaut's name is Quinn. I especially like his space boots.
The undeniable  revitalizing blossoms of Spring. All the sweeter after this winter.

A Mountie on a borrowed snowmobile chases a thief getting away on a tractor  though the snow. Imagine. I love Canada.  http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/rcmp-chase-stolen-tractor-through-alberta-fields-1.1760117
If there are aliens  they likely look like the Moss Piglet: it can survive 10 years with no food  water  and in the vacuum of space.
Olympian Hayley Wickenheiser - my goofy smile shows what a delight it is to meet her. A hockey legend & role model.
Great night at the Vogue Theatre in Vancouver. New music after a full day at TED. Thanks all for staying late!
This wristwatch costs about the same as a spaceflght on Virgin Galactic. http://www.coolhunting.com/style/sihh-2014-van-cleef-arpels-midnight-planetarium.php
Aerial view of Mexico City  one of the 10 biggest cities on Earth. Visual complexity of intertwined lives (Pablo Luz).
I post this cheek-tongued portrait  accepting the risk that the Moon landing deniers will try to use it as evidence.
My Dad is nearing 80  a little deaf  & thinking of getting hearing aids. I'm hoping he goes for the portable ones.

Congrats Gavin Zen Pencils for your originality  skill & tenacity. Look forward to your book!   http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/350437/lifestyle/literature/book-talk-zen-pencils-comic-transcends-internet-into-book-deal
Thank you  athletes  for being the best of us. My favorite part was to see the faces of the Moms and Dads in the audience. Canadian Olympic Team / Équipe olympique canadienne
Up early in Calgary  watching the Olympic hockey final. No such thing as an unassisted goal - cliche but true. Go Canada!
Many millions of Canadians just raised their clenched fists in the air & cheered  all together. What a superb hockey game. On to the finals!
This tall  skilled goalie played phenomenal hockey today. Congrats Kristers Gudlevskis & Team Latvia (but glad Canada won!)
Good morning! Reflections on a rocket launch. Florida photo by James Vernacotola.
A happy Canadian  top of hill. Recognize where?
Last year was off the planet  the year prior it wasn't allowed due to injury risk  but today I'm going skiing. Sun's shining. Wish me luck!
Mars sends love to us all on Valentine's Day - hearts abounding from the romantics at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory
Happy Valentine's Day! A beloved picture of the heart of Corfu  from a year ago today.
Fusion power. This is really important; 2 big steps forward from the Livermore scientists. http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/nuclear-fusion-hits-energy-milestone-1.2534140
I'm the only person in the Las Vegas airport who just pumped his fist and cheered out loud. Great goal  Meghan! Canadian Olympic Team / Équipe olympique canadienne
Salt water is flowing down the slopes of Mars  like tears on her cheeks mourning oceans lost. http://www.nasa.gov/jpl/mro/martian-seasonal-flow-20140210/#.Uvp1RPldV8l
The Rockies in my window. Well-named.
Velcro is like wallpaper on Space Station  effortlessly holding things in weightless place. A microscope shows how.
Gordon Lightfoot  first meeting with an old friend. His genius & style had a huge influence on how I think of music.
Perspective. Talking with Peter Mansbridge in front of a photo I took of our Earth and Moon. Wondrous distraction.
Good morning! Starting the Monday laughing at this Space Oddity spoof: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TJIZlAehgJY
Good morning! It was daunting to sing at the game last night. I'm glad I didn't mess it up  & that the Leafs won!   http://video.mapleleafs.nhl.com/videocenter/console?id=541078&catid=802
He shoots  he scores! Hockey is all about aiming accuracy. Practice every chance you can.
Good morning! After 26 years in Russia  the US & off the planet  we awoke today in our own house back in Canada. Snowy  sweet  beloved home.
Good morning! Four wee girls teaching me to speak Irish - in the lilt of Irish giggles you can hear the angels sing.
A sunset like no other  unbeaten January beauty on Ireland's Wild Atlantic Way. Like standing in a painting.
Good morning! Hurling is a fast  skilled sport (& thanks all for the clarification on names & places - I'm learning!)
Good morning! Who and what is where in the British Isles? I found this to be a helpful summary. Is it all correct?

Good Morning  Ireland! Happily headed to Dublin and Belfast  hoping to learn a cúpla focals: http://www.irishtimes.com/business/sectors/transport-and-tourism/astronaut-chris-hadfield-to-be-irish-tourism-ambassador-1.1649318
Good morning! This is a gigantic telescope. Today I'm here at Jodrell Bank  Stargazing with Dara Ó Briain and Prof. Brian Cox.
20 million hits! I am so delighted with the worldwide reaction to science & art  together: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KaOC9danxNo&feature=share&list=PLPfak9ofGSn9gG6a0lfE_oqGlFlo9Ypl_
Good morning! Somehow I feel that Prof. Brian Cox makes for a better paper doll: http://madartlab.com/2013/09/23/brian-cox-paper-doll/

Good morning! 100-yr-old images of exploration  at the edge of human capability and understanding in the Antarctic: http://www.imaging-resource.com/news/2013/12/27/on-ice-100-year-old-negative-discovered-in-antarctic-ice
Good morning! Earthrise - first view from the dark side of the Moon  Apollo 8  45 yrs ago this week. Self-awareness.  i.imgur.com/o8Zidve.gif
Good morning - Merry Christmas! May the day find you with family  friends  peace and joy. http://youtu.be/YufsbE4-jmY
Intelligence is the ability to adapt to change. Words of a brilliant  adaptive man whose muted courage is a lesson.
Good morning! It's December 19  exactly one year since I left Earth  a thought-provoking 365 days. Looking forward to Xmas  time to reflect.
Good morning  London! Perspective at night. Meeting folks & signing books today at Waterstone's Piccadilly  3 PM.
Wow - this is very cool! Thanks for the skill  patience and the higher purpose of your work.   http://imgur.com/jseZTa1
Good morning! Penny for your thoughts - this 1909 Lincoln is stuck to the side of Mars Curiosity. That's Martian dust.
Good morning! Perspective - the Aral Sea was our 4th largest lake  now gone due to bad policy  visible from space.
The Mounties always get their man  thus  I've been got.
Good morning! An ejected underwear moment from discussions with Conan last night. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C1j6KLP492E.   PS - Conan is tall in person!
This is something I never thought I'd see. Looking forward to talking with Conan onstage - a fun day!
Good morning - on this 11 Nov I honour AJ Hadfield  my great grandfather. Fought in WW1 & 2  lost his brother there.   Lest I forget.
Good morning! With the extra hour's sleep of the time change  I hereby present my doppelganger instead.
Good morning! I am going to see my daughter today  for the first time since I got back to Earth. I am very excited. Hugs galore!
What a fun Halloween! It was tough to choose from so many great applicants  but this wee astronaut gripped my heart.
Today I met a strip of bacon.
The beauty of launch day is that's when an idea meets reality. Three publishers  3 covers - very exciting for me!
Thanks to Donal Troddyn for helping me run my first ever Dublin Marathon!
I'm glad to see people preparing their Halloween costumes for my contest. Remember - there will be free prizes!
The Earth smiles broadly as the Sun rises.
Perspective on Central Park. Helicopter imagery sewn into one.   http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-2260276/New-York-youve-seen-Incredible-interactive-panorama-lets-zoom.html
Good morning! Perspective in time - NASA engineers prepare a PowerPoint slide in 1961. (LIFE magazine)
In the Green Room at SCITS high school  ready to go talk space  music and life with 1000 students. Wish me luck.
A lovely picture of the Great Lakes  taken by Karen Nyberg up on Space Station. One fifth of the world's fresh water.
Good morning! Perspective: first you have to get above the air - then your ship can go fast enough to stay in orbit.
I wish everyone a fine Canadian Thanksgiving holiday weekend. There is so much to be grateful for. Take the time.
Good morning! Came across this photograph from long ago - a moment where dreams  reality and promise met in person.
Scott Carpenter has died - Mercury astronaut  friend  inspiration. One of our best. Rest in peace.

Good morning! When I studied at U Waterloo never thought I'd return as a prof! Looking forward to working w/students. http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/out-of-this-world-enrolment-chris-hadfield-to-teach-at-university-of-waterloo-1.1488840
A quick video about the making of this Bowie tribute portrait: http://www2.macleans.ca/2013/10/02/behind-the-scenes-on-our-chris-hadfield-cover/
Good morning! I flew F-18s  commanded ISS & lived on the ocean floor  but it all pales; I was a factoid on Jeopardy.
Some selfies are more thought-provoking than others. Amazing what you can see in the reflection.
Walk in the Fall sun on Georgian Bay  gaze across to Blue Mountain. Our beautiful Earth.
Good morning! Some views are wonderful to wake up to. Even from orbit  Niagara Falls was a wonder of the world.
Good morning! It's pretty exciting to actually hold the book I wrote in my hand. Like being a new parent again!
Two good things about the haircut I just got here: my hair is shorter  and I'm still alive. Barber Erwin's a cut-up.
Retro-rockets fire! Great shot from a hovering helo as the Soyuz slammed back to Earth last night. NASA/Bill Ingalls
Homeward bound - 3 of my Space Station crewmates are plummeting to Earth tonight: Pavel  Chris  Sasha - soft landings
The dilemma of weightlessness. If I had a nickel for every time this happened ... (thanks to PDL Comics)
Good morning! Perspective - even after 5 months off the planet  this map looks odd to me. Subtle bias.
Good Morning! Had a fine flight over Toronto yesterday with those who represent us so well. https://www.facebook.com/CF18Demo
Good morning! Who's driven the furthest - on another world? I was surprised to see the answer.
Europe in Chinese - literal meaning of the names. I found it really interesting to read why: http://www.haohaoreport.com/l/41985
Good morning! 54 years ago today I was a breech birth  nearly killing my mother after a 3-day labour. Thanks Mom! - glad we both made it :)
I Have a Dream is an immensely powerful personal statement. MLK  I honour you today  what these 50 years changed  and the work left to do.
Today I fixed a broken toilet. Sometimes it's the little things that remind me of spaceflight...
If you release 29 000 rubber duckies into the ocean  where do they end up? http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friendly_Floatees - Our cool world.
My Dad collects tractors. He has 28 of them. It was fun helping him show them today at his farm. I love my parents.
Good morning! Moustache's everywhere - even on a full-scale solid butter ET. His finger glows unmelted.
I just stood on my dock & watched the Space Station soar overhead  then flare rapidly red to black into orbital sunset. A magic I've tasted.
Zachary is 5  and does portraiture. Astronauts on request. Thanks Zach!
It took this many brushes to make my face ready for a magazine photo-shoot. I'm NOT anybody's next top model.
Good Morning! The Earth has a bit of a weight problem - it's gaining about 100 tons per day.
Good morning! Very cool artwork. Does anyone know who the artist is? My subtle guess is that they are Brazilian.
I am being carved in butter - life-sized! That's never happened to me before (I think). Cool!
I love this book cover. What would you put on the cover if it were yours?
This is what a micro-meteorite hole looks like; found after landing in Space Shuttle Endeavour's radiator.
Or to look at it another way ...
Good morning! Perspective - how big is our Moon?
Good morning! Perspective - Sunday is a fine day to go for a walk with a friend.
Good morning! Perspective - Bruce McCandless had a view of the world like no other in history. Imagine what he saw.
Good morning! Perspective - the Space Station silhouetted by the Moon. It seems bigger from the inside.
Good morning! Perspective - our Earth & Moon  to scale in size and distance. So near  and yet ...
Sometimes you find someone who has said it very well - I agree with Woodrow. Do you?
Good Morning! Your perspective part 2; Buzz said "I could actually sense that Neil and I were standing on a sphere".
Good morning! Sometimes it's just a matter of perspective.
Good morning! Niagara Falls - beautiful from any angle.

I hate having to ban people. I want it clear that I don't wish to stifle any discussion  criticism  or disagreement to the posts here. If you disagree with me  Dad  or another person's comment  I'm happy for you to express the logic and reason behind your disagreement. I don't consider myself to be by any means smarter or more educated about our world than anyone else here  and am happy to get input from all of you to help better my own understanding.  What I can't stand is someone dominating conversation with insults  attacks  and out of place rudeness. If your purpose here is to insult people first and foremost  you're not welcome here.  - Evan
Edible planets - in delicious detail  made by an Aussie zoologist named Rhiannon. Perfect! http://www.thisiscolossal.com/2013/08/planetary-cakes/
Canadarm  the Earth  and the tiny crescent Moon - a still life.
The Moon has given us months  tides and a destination that ever-beckons. It's time we build a rocket and go to stay.
44 years ago today Mike  Buzz & Neil took us to the Moon. They inspired me like no other. Eternal thanks.
Alex Colville - to have believed in your imagination and expressed it to the fullest is to have lived. RIP.
I stayed up late one night in April to catch the morning light on the artwork that is the Outback.
It may seem like looking into a microscope  but this is actually the Iranian countryside  as-seen from orbit.

Good Morning! I found the last 45 sec of this short lightning video fascinating -  beautiful to see & educational: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RLWIBrweSU8&a=&feature=youtu.be&desktop_uri=%2Fwatch%3Fv%3DRLWIBrweSU8%26feature%3Dyoutu.be%26a
July morning  swim after a run  idyllic time and place to be a dog.
A friend just sent me this photo I took of a river and farmland in Brazil. The delicacy mesmerizes me.
Good morning  after a long walk with 3 dogs. A refreshing way to be reminded of the available simplicity of life.
Good Morning! After 2 months back on Earth  went for my 1st run yesterday. Felt clumsy & awkward & winded - & great! Building bone back.
*Blue Alberta sky  fine place to live.*
Man and horse  after the parade  happy to have met so many people and helped open the Stampede together. Thanks  Jag.
One horsepower - Jag and I are ready to ride!
Good Morning! Time to ride a big white horse as parade marshal to help open the 101st Calgary Stampede. Clear and cool  good waving weather!
If you were suddenly singing on the Stampede stage  what song would you choose? I went with Long Black Veil.
Thanks everyone for all the nice words and best wishes. After 35 years  retirement feels very new and odd. Walking on a new path.
Good morning  from the 1st day of my retirement. Headed to Calgary for the Stampede  booted  looking forward to seeing everyone there!
Stampede 101 - get boots to be Marshal for the parade. I love how these turned out! They have that new boot smell.
Canada Day was SO much fun! This photo by David Johnson helps captures the joy and rarity of it all.
Hey everyone! Sorry I couldn't post for the last two days. I was enjoying Canada Day in Ottawa  helping Dad. I hope everyone else had as much fun as we did!  - Evan
Bonjour  Montreal! Thanks everyone for the good wishes about the award. An honour to meet with our Governor General.
Istanbul waters - the sunglint shows how the Black Sea water flows through the Bosphorus.
A new elementary school bearing my name is a high honour and responsibility! http://www.scdsb.on.ca/About%20Us/Pages/NewsDetails.aspx?NewsId=936&y=2013 … What will they name their sports teams?
Not what I wanted to see 3 minutes before Skyping with CTV Calgary this morning!
Today my daughter got added to the bone marrow registry in Ireland  where she lives. I'd like to follow her example. How do I in Canada?
Sun glint turns a thousand miles of rivers into a single veined leaf.
2 friends just did a 6.5-hour spacewalk  readying Station for the new Russian laboratory. Good work Fyodor & Sasha!
Good morning! I love how some people have fun with the mundane - and create a personal expression of art!
It took about the same time to drive from Houston to Canada as it did from Kazakhstan to the Space Station. Different fast food enroute.
After 26 years serving in other places around the world  tonight I am back on Canadian soil  to stay. It feels so very good to be home.
Swan Song. On last night before leaving Houston  our band played a couple tunes. Song choice? Moondance :)
Floods are an unbridled misery. My heartfelt thoughts and wishes for a swift recovery to those battling the Alberta high waters.
My last morning with NASA. They said "1 last thing before you go" Good to the last drop! Headed home to Canada today.
Green man lake. I can't help but see human faces in the natural shapes and colours.
A perfect likeness  in crochet! I love the fine attention to detail.
Two Commanders. A delight to be with 4 1/2-year old Daniel-James in his astronaut suit and happy smile.
A rare sight at the Gagarin Cosmonaut Training Center  last week in Star City  Russia. Does my heart proud.
Hawaiian lava  like Japanese ink.
It was beautiful in Star City  Russia last week. In winter hardy locals swim through a hole in the ice in that pond.
It somehow felt like this lake was looking at me.
Happy Fathers' Day  Dad! A guiding example & voice in my head all my life. You're not on Twitter  so I'll call you :)
It surprised me to see that Corsica still had snow in May. And a spider's egg cloud.
My daughter made this fine felt likeness of me years ago  has adorned my office nametag since. Note Tin Tin's rocket.
Office pack-up - before picture. This Nat Geo Moon poster was above my bed growing up. Reminds and inspires me.
Good morning! Boxing up my office at NASA today after 21 years here. An atypical collection of things and emotions. It's so long been home.
I love this picture - the real 3D jumble of being people in a spaceship.
A nice quote from my FB wall: "My 4 yr-old thinks you should retire and study snails. I believe that you should remain a public promoter of science more generally".
The ultrasound technologist told me I have very nice bladder inlet ducts. I felt strangely complimented and said 'thank-you'. So proud.
Good Morning! A photo with Yuri Gagarin. Tom  Roman and I at Friday's welcome home ceremonies in Star City  Russia.
At the NASA Johnson Space Center  you need to watch your step. Easy to tell I'm back in southeast Texas!
Reading the so many notes of support and thanks. A lovely and thoughtful end to a big day for me. I thank each of you for taking the time.
To say goodbye to these good people today was much harder than I expected.
Good Morning! On my way to breakfast with the Prime Minister and his wife. A high honour for this Canadian.
The Earth gleams against the black and blue.
Good Morning  Canada! Recognize where I woke up? Gorgeous morning for a walk  out to get a little June sun on my face.
Back in Canada! On the ground at Montreal airport. Been welcomed home by so many people already  warms my heart  like reuniting with family.
Vancouver  with the Fraser River flowing full  roiling Spring run-off from the Rockies.
Just south of the Galapagos  this cloud is waiting for you to draw a face.
Good Morning! This Russian church is just outside my quarters in Star City - it's also my screensaver.
Gibraltar has a busy harbour.
Bandella at the end of the reunion concert  circa 1 AM. Beloved friends and musicians all.
This Cuban coral reef redefines the colour blue.
One straight human line drawn onto incredibly rough terrain.
Sudbury  Ontario  rich in nickel and copper  the ore put there by an asteroid impact 2 billion years ago.
Good morning  Saturday! Saw the Star Trek Movie last night. It made me really think & feel about where I've been; need to reconcile it all.
Hard brown ship of rock  adrift on a sea of salt.
Delicate fan of farms sharing the water as it flows from the hills  China.
Lisbon  Portugal  clear and bright on a Spring day.
Thanks to Lord Mayor Naoise Ó Muirí for bestowing such an honour  and all in Ireland who have supported throughout.
My daughter having fun at the Dublin Lord Mayor's Awards on my behalf. The mace is from 1718  the sword from 1410.
Good morning! Got together with friends last night to play music. The guitar felt so heavy  but stable; the harmonies lighter than air. Fun!
Winnipeg  with winter passed  fields turning green  river and spillway look full.
Lord Mayor of Dublin Award - a singular honour! Many thanks to my daughter Kristin for attending on my behalf.
Not sure  but I think that's a field of sand dunes covered in snow.
Lake Baikal  Siberia  immensely deep  ancient waters  locked under late winter ice.
Dip your brush  paint something from this Chinese mining town's palette.
Bahamas Blues Festival.
Tortured rock where India crashed into Asia and pushed up the Himalayas.
Good Morning! Time to get some sun on my face  after 5 months in an aluminum cave. But first - 2 hours of physical rehab. Getting there.
Sunlight on the water reflects the many bays of Newfoundland  like vertebra of rock.
Spaceflight Photos! Just got a copy of the 25 000 or so images of our 5 months in orbit. Big smiles on docking day.
Good Morning! At Earth impact the Soyuz fires optimistically-named 'soft landing rockets'. Here's how ours looked.
Africa blurs my eyes to the endless horizon.
To inspire art in others is a rare reward. Thanks to Lauren Crawford for sharing her talent.

Good article in The Economist. I'm very glad we were methodical and legal with David Bowie's creation. http://www.economist.com/blogs/economist-explains/2013/05/economist-explains-12?fsrc=scn/tw/te/bl/ee/copyrightinspace
The mouth of the Nile and the Red Sea  Cairo brightly lit.
Our Earth is just simply beautiful.
Art deco farming.
Good Morning! Space Station appears to be back to normal power and cooling today  as a result of our crew's spacewalk. That feels very good.
The Isle of Portland looks like an interesting place - the type I'd like to visit now that I'm back on Earth.
The only thing that delights me more than this picture is imagining her thoughts.
Good Morning! I've been back a week  and finally feel like I have my legs under and my wits about me. Seems landing on a planet takes time.
Today's photo is a river doing impersonations: Look  I'm a Stag Beetle!
Heart and lungs  on the cardio machine to see exactly how bodies readapt. I have empathy for the cries of newborns.
My Leafs shirt and Russian long underwear  still soaked with sweat from the fiery re-entry  ready for the laundry.
Look deep into my eyes. Dr. Gibson uses all the tools to see how I see. It appears my eyes were unchanged. Yay!
Hot smokestack exhaust streams in the harsh wind across a central Asian winter landscape.
Good morning from NASA JSC - today I get eye tests  see if weightlessness changed my vision  as it has for some. Also med tests & physio.
Today's photo is of Argentina. A tongue of mud lashing in the river's mouth.
Apparently this is a good place to drill for water  in Saudi Arabia.
Good Morning! Played some guitar last night with friends for the 1st time since landing  don't have full breath yet  but so sweet to hear.
Today's photo is Mallorca. Wow. Please remind me to go there when I'm fully recovered.
Good Morning! To test my balance readaptation today I drive a motion simulator of a car  T-38 jet & Mars rover. Plus rehab physio & interviews.
With the research team from U Waterloo. Danielle  Richard and Andrew studying the body's circulatory system controls.
Today's photo is of the rising Moon. How could anyone have ever thought the world was flat?
Spent 75 minutes imaging my innards in this MRI. You'd think I'd at least come out with a tan!
This is your brain  on Earth. ESA neurological experiment measuring brainwave changes as I adapted to and from 0G.
You know you're back on Earth when you suddenly have to watch where you put your feet. One small step for man...
How I earned my breakfast this morning. Welcome back to Earth.
Good Morning from the Johnson Space Center! Happy to report that my body and balance feel much better. Today I'm going without the G-suit.
Today's photo is sunrise  the windows glinting and solar array gilded in the unbelievably harsh morning light.
My left hand  all wired-up to measure how my body is readapting to gravity. Part of a Japanese university study.
Wired head  chest  arms and feet  learning how the body works when it has been weightless for half a year.
Good Morning from Houston! First chance today to talk with Canadian media  try and describe the wonder of the experience. + physiotherapy.

I took a few thousand more photos in space than I was able to post. I'll try to update from here on out with at least one per day.  Today's photo is from the Mongolian highlands. Surreal to see a frozen lake surrounded by sand dunes.
How does the body control blood pressure? Scarecrow on a tilt table to measure how.
It's cliche  but this is my 1st meal back on Earth. The smell is like an old friend.
Return to Gravity  so many things. It is strange to talk and feel the weight of my lips and tongue! Dizzy too - would fail any sobriety test.
Shower door in NASA astronaut quarantine facility. I think I want one at home.
I've just been through my Twitter  Facebook & email welcomes home - am overwhelmed. Thanks to everyone who took the time to write. So nice.
Good Morning  Earth! 1st real morning back on the planet  still dizzy & jet-lagged  full NASA sched of med tests and rehab. So much 2 tell!
Good to back in Houston at Johnson Space Center - sort of: 14 vials of blood  now on to coordination tests. Welcome home :)
Forgot to mention: first long  hot shower since December. That felt so good! Step 1 of Return to Earth complete.
On the ground in Prestwick   Scotland  to refuel. Blue sky day  Nature smiling on us. Was 1st here in 1977 - who could have predicted this?
Safely home - back on Earth  happily readapting to the heavy pull of gravity. Wonderful to smell and feel Spring.
(Evan's note) Touchdown! Welcome back to Earth  Dad.
(Evan's note) Deorbit burn and landing coverage on NASA tv starts now: http://www.nasa.gov/multimedia/nasatv/index.html
(Evan's note) Wonder what it looks like in the Soyuz capsule? I think the term they prefer is "cozy".
Spaceflight finale: To some this may look like a sunset. But it's a new dawn.
Reviewing Soyuz procedures onboard  but I wanted to thank every person at the Cdn Space Agency. Your work takes Canada into orbit. Be proud.
Our solar arrays  like the Earth's atmosphere  are thin  beautiful and vital for keeping us alive.
Clouds swoop in on Crimea  a white bird on the Black Sea.
The southwest corner of Africa  from space.
Good morning  Earth! We're supposed to be sleeping late to be rested for tonight's Soyuz flight home  but I'm finding it hard to sleep in.
Tonight's Finale: Boston  you're a beautiful harbor city. Hope your Bruins play a memorable game tonight vs the Leafs.
Canada rocks.
With deference to the genius of David Bowie  here's Space Oddity  recorded on Station. A last glimpse of the World. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KaOC9danxNo
Spaceships glowing blue in the dawn as we leave Florida headed across the Atlantic.
Almost time to leave Station. Hard to express all of my emotions  but mostly gratitude. I came here on behalf of so many people - thank you.
It's Mothers' Day today  please don't forget. I ordered flowers for my Mom & am about to give her a call. Don't tell  she's not on Facebook :)
Dr. Seuss-inspired swirls in the Black Sea.
Good Morning  Earth! Today I proudy hand command of Space Station to Pavel Vladimirovich Vinogradov. Time to rev up the Soyuz  home.
Tonight's Finale: The Moon rising over a bed of cloud. A constant reminder to us all of what can be achieved.
Chris and Tom  helmet lights doing their best to light the universe on the dark side of the Earth.
Amazing day. EVA went off without a hitch. Great crew  phenomenal ground support and a supportive audience. Who could ask for anything more?
Here's looking at you. Chris and Tom take a minute with visors to look up-sun at my camera in the window.
Chris Cassidy  Navy SEAL and lead spacewalker today. The nicest iron man you'll ever meet.
No leaks! We're bringing Tom & Chris back inside. In two days Tom  Roman & I return to Earth in our Soyuz. This is an amazing place & time.
Scotland and the Spring sunshine peeking at each other over the clouds.
Big storm swirling off the Irish coast on the 9th of May.
The whole team is ticking like clockwork  readying for tomorrow. I am so proud to be Commander of this crew. Such great  capable  fun people
Tonight's Finale: A view to put the mind at ease.
San Francisco and California wine country - a favourite place on Earth.
Cape Town  South Africa and the South Atlantic calling to forever.
Tonight's Finale: A long lens view of thunderstorms over the Amazon.
Same land  different politics. The US - Mexican border  seen from space.
Tonight's Finale: Moonset  one of 16 per day on ISS  all marvelous to see.
Good to know that after 5 months  my Sokhol pressure suit still fits. It's what we wear in the Soyuz. High fashion.
Tonight's Finale: Our Sun is immensely  unfathomably powerful.
Tonight's Finale: Huron  Erie and Ontario - Great Lakes in Spring flow.
The highlands of Cape Breton still wear the winter's snow  sun highlighting the connecting waters.
Gaspe like a giant beast  sloughing off the last of the winter's snow.
Tonight's Finale: Toronto. Go Leafs Go!
The southern UK  as-seen from the ISS.
There is no try - only do. May the 4th be with you.
Happy Star Wars Day  May the 4th be with you! :)
Tonight's Finale: The starkest of beauty  in Saudi Arabia.
Tonight's Finale: Overhead of Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic  floating above our glowing blue sphere.
While the Newfoundland ice formed a heraldic dragon  these Pacific clouds look more like Woodstock  of Peanuts fame.
A heraldic Spring dragon of ice roars rampant off the coast of Newfoundland.
It turns out that onions DO make you cry in space  too. Just here  tears don't fall.
Space Onion - came up on the Progress resupply spaceship. We sliced it up and had it with everything - nice flavor!
Tonight's Finale: The Moon ushering in the dawn over the Southeastern United States.
I think Brianna will be a fine astronaut. The Right Stuff  in miniature.
Tonight's Finale: Dubai  the Palm Island like a trilobite in the night.
An astronaut's perspective on the Canadian Maritimes.
Talked with Neil Young tonight  he in his hybrid 1959 Lincoln  my in a spaceship. Discussed Earth ecology & writing music. A heart of gold.
The yin and yang of ice and land at Lake of the Woods.
The Greek islands  like delicate shattered eggshell pieces.
The flag of Cyprus shining in the sun on what must have been an absolutely beautiful day.
Tonight's Finale: The Galapagos - just far enough apart to give Darwin something to think about.
Nova Scotia and her surrounding waters  the land showing the first green of Spring.
The red soil that makes Prince Edward Island's potatoes so famous is visible from space.
Tonight's Finale: Our Moon  tinted blue  made so by the wisp of Earth's atmosphere.
Ancient Saharan stone  burnished by eternal sand and wind.
Southern UK and Pas de Calais. The lights act like a census.
Tonight's Finale: A Dali watch on an alligator wristband - Mexico.
The beautiful and violent ugliness inside a naked volcano. Chad  Africa.
Lake Balaton  Hungary. A lovely vacation destination on the water with spring's new growth visible all around.
If you fly in space  this a great group to be with  surrounded by talent: Pavel  Tom  Chris  Roman & Alexander.
Tonight's Finale: Distorted by the lens of the Earth's atmosphere  the Moon rises over a bed of cloud.
The effortless natural art of the southern Sahara.
Athens  Greece. The Parthenon at the heart stands out from orbit.
Tonight's Finale: New York City  incredibly clear  before the trees have filled with leaves.
Snowbirds from Space! Canada’s premiere aerobatic team  photographed from orbit. Amazingly clear  and great timing!
Ireland  Wales and Mann silhouetted in the setting sun.
Wales - rugged  proud and uniquely beautiful.
Tonight's Finale: In proportion  our atmosphere is no thicker than the varnish on a globe. Deceptively fragile.
Huge congratulations to the Maple Leafs for making it into the NHL Playoffs! Looking forward to watching from orbit.
I have never had more love and respect for our planet than I do now  seeing it this way.
Looking out the windows of ISS  every day is Earth Day.
Tonight's Finale: Halifax  site of NFB Space School launch and final talk with press on Mon. - http://www.asc-csa.gc.ca/eng/media/advisories/2013/0418.asp
Canadarm2 gives a thumbs-up to the World.
Today's Space Brunch - waffles  Cdn maple syrup  freeze-dried strawberries  jerky  instant OJ & coffee. Delicious!
How would a candle burn without gravity? An onboard experiment called BASS shows us  here where heat doesn’t rise.
The Australian Outback is effortlessly crazily beautiful.
Strange contrail - my guess is an IFR holding pattern  or an Air Force tanker waiting for customers.
Good Morning  Earth! I'm making breakfast for the crew: toaster waffles w/ real maple syrup  freeze-dried strwberries  jerky  OJ  coffee.
Tonight's Finale: Southern Ontario  with the hard rock of the Canadian Shield visible from orbit.
St Lawrence's mouth  where the Great Lakes pour into the sea.
Unusual perspective of the Great Lakes.
Prince Edward Island waits for the greening of Spring.
Nova Scotia on a clear early Spring day.
Tonight's Finale: Newfoundland glowing on a lovely Spring evening.
Roman Yurievich Romanenko  outside in the universe for the very 1st time. A wondrous experience.
Psychedelic ice swirls off the North Japan coast.
Tonight's Finale: Catching the Moon rising takes patience  but is worth it.
Paris  well-named City of Light. Even from orbit the brilliant Champs-Elysees is visible.
Berlin at night. Amazingly  I think the light bulbs still show the East/West division from orbit.
Tonight's Finale: Toronto  Ontario. Interesting the different things that become more visible at night.
Tonight's Finale: A somber Spring night in Boston.
La ville de Montreal brille sur une nuit de printemps.
A snail island in the waters around Indonesia  with transparent insides.
I recently found that I have a number of blind followers  & I want to do right by them: I will record & tweet more sounds of the Station.
I'm used to rivers that know what they're doing.
Tonight's Finale: Patagonia to the Pacific  the glaciers showing the height of the southern Andes.
Cloud vortex spinning its wheels on the Chilean coast.
Patagonia glacier - thousands of years of climate history  coldly moving in ultra slow motion.
Tonight's Finale: People ask to see stars - my camera does its best in dim light. Our atmosphere glows in the dark.
These Great Barrier Reef islands make me want to draw in the second eye.
Tonight's Finale: I have no idea what this Brazilian outcrop looks like on the ground  but from orbit  it's a brain.
Joao Pessoa  Brazil  easternmost city in the Americas - where the sun rises first.
Sometimes Mother Nature uses a protractor  like here in New Zealand's South Island.
Tonight's Finale: Italy  heel and toe.
Tonight's Finale: Our golden lights from Dublin to Paris  Nature's from green aurora to blue dawn.
A clear Dublin night in early Spring.
To commemorate the passing of the Iron Lady  in the centre of these London lights is #10 Downing Street.
Tonight's Finale: Aurora dances above a ribbon of dawn.
The river hiccups like a zipper on an old coat.
Tonight's Finale: Morning in NYC. Downtown Manhattan casts quite a shadow.
Morning jet traffic over San Francisco.
Tonight's Finale: Vancouver  twinkling brightly early on Easter Sunday morning.
A island off the Pacific coast of Mexico spins clouds into swirls of lace.
Fogo  a volcano so big it peaks above the Atlantic. Last active 18 years ago.
Sun getting ready to set into the horizon of Southwestern Australia.
Tonight's Finale: Our Earth is mostly liquid rock. We live on a thin crust  with occasional hot spots  like Mt. Etna.
To slowly change gears from the day's amusement - something light. Right after I took this picture I ate the cookie.
I don't know what it is or what it wants  but it keeps repeating "Sloof Lirpa" over and over. Alert the press.
Wow  what a huge piece of debris! Maybe I can grab it with the Canadarm2...
Orbital debris seems to be on a course moving a bit faster than ISS. I'll try to take more pictures if it swings by.
Easter Finale: The Sun  a bright point of light surrounded by profound blackness  our world glowing in-between.
A Full Moon. It may not be made of chocolate  but it makes for a wonderfully natural Easter egg.
It appears that I'm as bad at juggling in weightlessness as I am on Earth. Hopefully I'm better at hiding them...
An Easter sunrise glints across the Great Lakes. Heartland watershed.
Don't tell my crew  but I brought them Easter Eggs :)
There may never be a clearer picture of the Isle of Wight from space.
Cuba  the Bahamas  Florida  the Universe.
The Florida Keys look especially vulnerable from orbit.

Our plants aren't looking too good. Would be a problem on Mars. I'm going to have to channel my inner Mark Watney. #YearInSpace

Look! It's the moon! By my toe! #YearInSpace

Working weekend aboard the International Space Station for likely #spacewalk Monday or Tuesday. No task is an easy job. Final decision tomorrow. Thank you for your patience as we work to prepare for outside repairs. Be with you again soon! #YearInSpace
Moving over mountains. Good morning and Happy Saturday from the International Space Station! #YearInSpace
Wait  these are the droids we're looking for. The Force Awakens with real bots on the International Space Station! #YearInSpace

No lines here for #StarWars  but we do have to wait for it to get up to the International Space Station. Soon it will be. Patience we must have  padawans! #YearInSpace
Get over your mountains with rock and grit. #YearInSpace

Soyuz arrived! Great to welcome the rest of our Exp 46 crew aboard the International Space Station today! #YearInSpace
Soyuz blasts through the atmosphere on its way to the International Space Station!

We're fewer at the dinner table on the International Space Station tonight as our three friends await to return to Earth.   But when we were nine people aboard the space station  it's a bit of a full house. It's been a solid  busy week since Andy  Sergei and Aidyn joined the rest of us. It's not every day you get to work with such a unique crew comprised of good people from five different countries: Russia  USA  Denmark  Japan and Kazakhstan.  At the end of the day  the dinner table acts as a unifier  a place of community. Sharing a meal gives us a chance to put aside work and catch up with one another. While nutrition is important to us physically - maintaining our health and mitigating the negative effects of microgravity on our bodies - mealtime also is important to us psychologically.  Dining together can radically shift perspectives  blurring boundaries just as looking down on Earth from our vantage point  especially  when dinner partners are from all different corners of the world. But also mealtime lets us build a sense of camaraderie.  Andy  Aidyn and Gennady - whom I launched to the International Space Station with nearly six months ago - will begin their journey home today. I will miss those guys. They are good friends to break bread with.  Eat simply  and eat together. #YearInSpace  Watch this video and others during my year in space on YouTube > https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCM-p4l2OPH_oX6tFrjKT-9A

Today we honor the crews of Apollo 1  Challenger and Columbia  heroes who lost their lives serving America’s space program. These astronauts and their families will always be a part of the NASA family  and we will continue to honor their contributions. Our Day of Remembrance commemorates not only the men and women lost in NASA's space exploration program and their courage  but celebrates human space exploration since then.    Apollo 1 (Jan. 27  1967): Astronauts Roger B. Chaffee  Virgil "Gus" Grissom and Edward H. White Jr.   Challenger (Jan. 28  1986): Astronauts Francis R. "Dick" Scobee  Michael J. Smith  Judith A. Resnik  Ronald E. McNair  Ellison S. Onizuka  Gregory B. Jarvis and S. Christa McAuliffe   Columbia (Feb. 1  2003): Astronauts Rick D. Husband  William C. McCool  Michael P. Anderson  David M. Brown  Kalpana Chawla  Laurel B. Clark and Ilan Ramon

Check out the wheels on that thing! This time-lapse shows the Space Exploration Vehicle which could be used to explore an asteroid  the moon  or Mars and can house two astronauts for up to 14 days with sleeping and sanitary facilities.   It can travel thousands of miles climbing over rocks and up 40 degree slopes during its ten year life. The vehicle frame was developed in conjunction with an off-road race truck team and was field tested in the desert Southwest with 140 km of driving on rough lava.  More: http://www.nasa.gov/exploration/technology/space_exploration_vehicle/index.html

The Hubble Space Telescope is celebrating its 25th birthday on Friday. Hubble  the world’s first space telescope  was launched on April 24  1990  aboard the space shuttle Discovery. In its quarter-century in orbit  the observatory has transformed our understanding of our solar system and beyond  and helped us find our place among the stars. For more information on the anniversary and events  visit: http://go.nasa.gov/1HMUHKI  Happy #Hubble25!

History has been made!   Orion Splashdown  NASA’s Orion Spacecraft splashed down in the Pacific Ocean approximately 600 southwest of San Diego. The recovery team from NASA  the U.S. Navy and Lockheed Martin will perform initial recovery operations  including safing the crew module and towing it into the well deck of the USS Anchorage  a landing platform-dock ship.

The United Launch Alliance Delta IV Heavy with NASA’s Orion Spacecraft atop it lifted off at 7:05 a.m. EST from Space Launch Complex 37 at Cape Canaveral Air Force Station in Florida. See photos on NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Flickr page: https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahqphoto/

Orion Soars on First Flight Test  NASA’s Orion Spacecraft launched successfully atop a United Launch Alliance Delta IV Heavy rocket Dec. 5 at 7:05 a.m. EST from Space Launch Complex 37 at Cape Canaveral Air Force Station in Florida. Orion’s Exploration Flight Test-1 (EFT-1)  is the first flight test for NASA’s new deep space capsule and is a critical step on NASA's journey to Mars. The 4.5 hour flight is scheduled to conclude with the splashdown of Orion in the Pacific Ocean.  Watch the launch video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UEuOpxOrA_0&feature=youtu.be   Watch live mission coverage: www.nasa.gov/ntv

NASA's Driven to Explore mobile exhibit is on the campus of Purdue University today. The exhibit shows how research aboard the International Space Station benefits people on Earth and honors the legacy of American achievement in space with one of only eight moon rocks in the world that visitors can actually touch.  The moon rock was returned to Earth by the crew of Apollo 17  commanded by '56 Purdue grad Gene Cernan.  Driven to Explore has no admission charge and is designed for all ages.

Tonight at the Indiana Medical History Museum  NASA astronaut Anna Fisher will give a presentation and answer questions about her experiences as a mission specialist aboard the STS-51A space shuttle mission. Fisher also is a medical doctor and currently works at NASA on the space station and Orion programs.  RSVP by email: education@imhm.org

NASA Administrator Charles Bolden addresses industry representatives attending the Commercial Resupply Services 2 Industry Day at NASA's Johnson Space Center. NASA is inviting industry innovation to continue resupplying cargo and delivering crucial research to the International Space Station.

NASA Administrator Charles Bolden and Johnson Space Center Director Ellen Ochoa learn more about the spacewalk tools being developed for a future mission to an asteroid. Collecting surface samples from an asteroid during a spacewalk presents new challenges.
NASA astronaut Dan Burbank briefs NASA administrator Charles Bolden on the challenges of modifying the shuttle era launch and entry suits for @Or

NASA's #DriventoExplore trailer will be at Houston Methodist Hospital for the 7th annual Pumps and Pipes event Dec. 9. The event with input from the Bay Area Houston Economic Partnership brings experts together from the Aerospace  Medicine and Energy industries and enables the exchange of ideas  knowledge and research to benefit society.

Thank you to our friends at the Alachua Astronomy Club for sharing this great photo and details. "Summer in Florida is not a friend to star gazers. Moist warm air rising over the Florida peninsular often brings extensive thunderstorms with abundant lightning  especially during afternoons and evenings. Last night was no exception. Active late evening thunderstorms brightly lit up north central Florida skies in the hours before midnight  2014 June 20  about 7-8 hours before the June solstice (6:51 a.m.  EDT June 21). Most lightning was cloud to cloud including sheet lightning that strongly illuminated the northern and western horizons from this location. Photo taken from southwest Gainesville  Florida looking northwest toward the cities of Alachua and High Springs. Picture Taken: 2014 June 20  11:36 p.m. EDT."

On June 29th 2012  destructive winds caused severe damage all the way from the Midwest to the Mid-Atlantic. Power was lost and homes were destroyed. No  this wasn’t a hurricane or a storm with lots of tornadoes. It was a special kind of windstorm known as a derecho. What is a derecho? Find out in the latest SciJinks article: http://scijinks.gov/derechos.

The creators of The Space Place proudly announce ‘Space Place Prime’ for iPad. ‘Prime’ gathers some of the best and most recent offerings from NASA  with engrossing articles from The Space Place  enlightening NASA videos  and gorgeous NASA images updating daily. Space Place Prime targets all ages—kids  teachers  parents  and space enthusiasts will find fascinating features on this new  free NASA app. Check it out! http://spaceplace.nasa.gov/ios .
Learn about a boy who decided to become a NASA scientist after finding a meteorite on the ground:  http://spaceplace.nasa.gov/space-place-live/#burnett

The first human  American Neil Armstrong  set foot on the Moon  July 20  1969.  Dr. Marc Rayman talks about some Moon landing challenges you may not have considered at http://spaceplace.nasa.gov/dr-marc-earth/en/#/review/dr-marc-earth/moon-meteroids.html.

Turn the beautiful Space Place home page into wearable art. Print the art onto iron-on transfer paper and put it on a t-shirt  or any other fabric. And iron a colorful solar system portrait onto the other side. Go to http://spaceplace.nasa.gov/t-shirt.

Even if you don’t have an iPhone or iPad  now you can play the exciting Comet Quest game  Flash version  right on The Space Place website! Learn about comets and the Rosetta mission. The game is like the real NASA/ESA mission  but with you in control of the spacecraft. Get going to a comet at http://spaceplace.nasa.gov/comet-quest.

A new fun fact page on The Space Place tells all about the upcoming Venus transit on June 5 and how to view it safely. Although the next Venus transit won’t happen until 2117  other more common types of eclipses happen a lot more often  and you can learn about them here too. http://spaceplace.nasa.gov/venus-transit
See a picture of Alan Shepard and others on the first American astronaut team now at The Space Place.

Thank you to the outstanding @John C. Wells Planetarium at JMU – one of our Community Partners for sharing this great post.  To find a Community Partner near you  visit http://spaceplace.nasa.gov/community-partners/en.

What’s it like to walk in the shoes of a meteorologist? They’re not all on TV  you know! Read a first-person account of a most passionate one  Tim Schmit  on “Mission Chronicles ” the Space Place blog written by scientists and engineers themselves. See http://spaceplace.nasa.gov/mission-chronicles/#schmit.

Practice recycling by playing “Recycle THIS!” on NASA’s Climate Kids website  http://climate.nasa.gov/kids/games/recycleThis. Using your tiny “Airburst” deflection tool  sort recyclables and trash into their proper bins. Music and sound effects help to spur you into becoming an expert recycler.

To understand ocean currents  start by learning two things: Salty water sinks  and warm water rises. Play the new “Go with the Flow” game on The Space Place and these important facts will become fun facts that you will not soon forget. Go to http://spaceplace.nasa.gov/ocean-currents.

“Shields Up!” is a new game on SciJinks  in which the player’s job is to keep three satellites safe from random blasts of damaging rays and particles from the Sun  while keeping the satellites operating as much as possible. Play “Shields Up!” at http://scijinks.gov/shields-up.

Download beautiful new Space Place desktop wallpapers. Pick from the home page graphic  or any of the theme backgrounds for space  Sun  Earth  solar system  people and technology  or parents and educators. Go to http://spaceplace.nasa.gov/wallpaper.

A sea of critical real-time weather data floods into the satellite’s memory grid! A storm full of tornadoes is brewing! The Sun is about to blast out a huge solar flare that could destroy satellites! To save lives and protect expensive instruments  the GOES-R weather satellite must not lose any of the data it is collecting. You can help! Play Satellite Insight  the brand new game by the Space Place. It’s also free in the iTunes App Store!
What is your favorite function for the NASA's The Space Place website?
Now  when you play games on The Space Place  you can post your scores to your Facebook page and challenge your friends to do better. Check it out!

Just as important as the spacecraft NASA sends to explore the solar system is the network of transceivers here at home that let us communicate with them. The new “Uplink-Downlink” game on The Space Place is a fun way to see how it works. The spacecraft are so far away  they might as well be stationary in the sky as Earth turns below. Three different antennas (dish-type radio telescopes) of the Deep Space Network (DSN) pass by one at a time below as Earth turns. Your job in the game is to aim the moving antenna at a spacecraft  transmit a command  then receive 100% of the data sent back from as many as five spacecraft before the game is over. Play “DSN Uplink-Downlink.”

Explore the whole solar system!  Next year  2011  is the Year of the Solar System  and we are getting a head start at The Space Place. “Solar System Explorer” is a super-game containing several mini-games. Pick a planet. Or a comet. Or an asteroid. Zoom in and poke around. If it’s a planet with moons  zoom in on one of them and explore even more. And if a spacecraft is already there  or headed there  play a mini-game to help the spacecraft with its mission of exploration. Earn achievements by reading about solar system objects and by playing the games. More mini-games are coming soon. See how high you can push your scores. Post them on your Facebook page. Start exploring now!
Want to do something to help the environment? This one's easy and fun. Help keep ozone where it will do the most good in the atmosphere  and get rid of it where it is harmful. Play Ozone Trap-n-Zap!

Play Photon Pile-up at The Space Place! In this fast-paced game  multi-colored photons rain in from all directions. They come from old stars  new stars  galaxies  and glowing gas.  Spin the Galaxy Evolution Explorer telescope around quickly to collect three photons of the same color and record the beautiful space image one piece at a time. This telescope detects ultraviolet  photons best  so those count most. Don’t let the sticky non-matching photons pile up too high  or the game will end before your picture is complete. Play Photon Pile-up. Don’t get too addicted!

A New Life for SciJinks!  Visit or revisit SciJinks.gov and discover the treasures you missed  before. It’s got a whole new persona to make its exciting content  games and multimedia more accessible than ever.  SciJinks still has its Picture and Cool Fact of the day.  It has “Wild Weather Adventure ” “Bad Weather Joke Machine ” and other fun and games. SciJinks explains the reasons for the seasons  the tides  and other mysteries in colorful “now I get it!” pages. There are more images than ever and now videos too  and lots of help for teachers. Looking for information on hurricanes? SciJinks also shows you its content by topic: clouds  tides  oceans  atmosphere  seasons  satellites—you name it.

The creators of The Space Place have another Website called SciJinks: Weather Laboratory. It targets middle-schoolers primarily. Lots of fun  games  and answers to questions you've always wondered about. SciJinks also has a new Facebook page. Become a fan!

Sign Here! Here's a new game en español. The Spitzer Space Telescope has taken spectacular images of spiral galaxies  clouds of glowing gas and dust  and star nurseries. The Spitzer team wants signs for displaying these images. Try this game  and have fun learning astronomy words in Spanish  and improving your typing skills. Go to http://spaceplace.nasa.gov/sp/kids/spitzer/signs.

No human can see infrared light. But the question is  can you think in infrared? Give your visual memory a workout with a few rounds of the Spitzer Infrared Concentration game at The Space Place. http://spaceplacenasa.gov/en/kids/spitzer/concentration.

Why is this meteor shower called the Perseids? Because the radiant (point in the sky which the meteors appear to come from) lies in the constellation Perseus! Here are radiants from this year's Perseids as seen in NASA's All Sky Fireball Network. Note: this does NOT mean that you should look towards Perseus to view them  rather look up and take in as much of the sky as possible. The Perseids will be seen all over the sky.

This diagram shows orbits of the 69 Perseids already seen in NASA's wide-field meteor cameras (green and blue)  against the orbit of comet Swift-Tuttle  the parent body of the Perseids (purple). There is some spread in the meteoroid stream due to planetary perturbations  however most of this spread is due to errors in the orbit determination. The Perseids have highly eccentric orbits  which lends itself to higher errors in the orbits of these meteors.

Riding on a Perseid - the previous video shows our view of the Perseid; this one shows the action from the Perseid's point of view. Starting a few days out  you will see the Moon fly by a few hours before it hits the atmosphere and the continents loom large as the meteoroid approaches the Earth. The video stops at an altitude of 54 miles  when the meteor meets its fiery demise (choose the HD option to see the details).

The annual eta Aquariid meteor shower will be best observed just before dawn tomorrow morning. Peak rates are normally around 40 meteors per hour  but the gibbous Moon will wash out the fainter etas  resulting in about 15-20 per hour under clear skies. This debris from Comet Halley hits Earth's atmosphere at a whopping 147 000 miles per hour (66 kilometers per second) and starts ablating (burning up) at altitudes around 68 miles (110 kilometers); most are vaporized by the time they reach 56 miles (90 kilometers) above the Earth's surface. The radiant rises late  so don't expect to see many etas before 3 AM local time.  Our all sky cameras have detected 22 eta Aquariid fireballs since April 29. The photo shows a -5 magnitude eta Aquariid captured by the Huntsville camera in the wee morning hours (3:33 AM CDT) of May 4.
Here is an animation showing the orbit of the Pennsylvania fireball and the meteor's perspective as it approaches Earth (imagine you were sitting on the meteor as it headed towards us).

Fireball over Pennsylvania!  This morning (2015 February 17)  a space rock about 2 feet in diameter and weighing roughly 500 pounds entered Earth’s atmosphere above western Pennsylvania. First detected by 3 NASA meteor cameras at an altitude of 60 miles above Beaver Falls  the fireball moved almost due east at a speed of 45 000 miles per hour. It flared brighter than the Full Moon before the cameras lost track of it at an altitude of 13 miles above the town of Kittanning; there may be fragments (meteorites) scattered on the ground east of that location. This celestial visitor had an orbit that took it out to the main asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter - it came a mightly long way to a fiery end in the predawn Pennsylvania sky.

Sunday night around 10:56 PM Eastern Time  a chunk of an asteroid weighing over 175 pounds entered the atmosphere over the northern part of Huntington County in Pennsylvania at a speed of 36 500 miles per hour. It was detected by four NASA all sky meteor cameras in Ohio and Pennsylvania at an altitude of 55 miles  moving slightly north of west. The fireball  which was close to a Full Moon in brightness  traveled across some 20 miles of Pennsylvania countryside before fragmenting in a brilliant flash of light 18 miles above a point just southeast of the town of Warrior’s Mark.  Video of the fireball (in Quicktime format) from Allegheny Observatory near Pittsburgh attached. An animation of the fireball’s orbit and the approach to Earth from its perspective is at http://fireballs.ndc.nasa.gov/special/Sep14_meteoroid.avi

Clouded out this year? You can still see Geminids! Go to http://fireballs.ndc.nasa.gov and click on the 20121214 or 20121213 links at the left  which will bring up data on the Geminids recorded on those nights.Click on a thumbnail to play the movie of the meteor (requires XVid codec)

The NASA fireball camera at the Tellus Museum in Cartersville  Georgia caught these nearly simultaneous fireballs at 5:44 AM EDT on May 6. The first is a faint streak just a bit above and to the right of the center of the image; the second - which is much brighter- immediately follows off to the right at the top edge of the clouds. These were not automatically picked up in our other cameras  so we do not have trajectories and cannot definitively identify them as eta Aquarids. However  an overlay of the star field (link below) suggests that they probably are  as the meteors appear to originate from close to the meteor shower radiant (the plus sign labeled ETA).  http://fireballs.ndc.nasa.gov/special/eAQR_2012/dbl_eta_Aqr.jpg

The NASA all sky meteor cameras detected 7 Eta Aquarid fireballs last night  6 of them between 3:45 and 4:30 a.m. PDT - a span of only 45 minutes! In this video  an Eta streaks at 152 000 mph above Las Cruces  New Mexico. At such speeds  the half-ounce piece of Halley's Comet lasts only a second before meeting a fiery demise 53 miles above Earth's surface.

We have started going though the data from the balloon meteor camera  and are seeing a fair number of meteors! A probable Lyrid flashes across the left side of this video; Mars is at the top right and fainter Saturn is towards top left. The lights of Bishop  California and ranches in the Owens Valley shine at the bottom.  I was hoping for at least 1 or 2 meteors  but so far we have at least 14  maybe as many as 30  which is beyond our wildest dreams. Needless to say  we are quite excited!
Speed  height  time  and magnitude distributions of the automated Lyrid detections by the NASA network so far this year

Update on Lyrid balloon flight  After a 3 hour journey  the meteor payload descended safely via parachute. However  it landed in a remote  hard to reach area of the White Mountains  so it will take time (days) for the recovery team to formulate a plan and get to it.  This is the first time the balloon team has had a payload land in such a tough area. Murphy's Law strikes again!

Daylight (8 AM) fireball over California on April 22  This was a large event! Elizabeth Silber at Western University puts its energy at around 3.8 kilotons of TNT based on the infrasound signals. Energy source coordinates are approximately 37.6N  120.5W (plotted on map).  News story: http://www.mynews4.com/news/local/story/Meteor-Tahoe-Sierra-Nevada-Reno-California-Lyrid/klZR_ppB0E-vnU9igyZ1Pw.cspx  Some eyewitness accounts here: http://www.amsmeteors.org/fireball2/public.php?start_date=2012-04-01&end_date=2012-04-31&state=&event_id=588&submit=Find+Reports  More accounts at http://lunarmeteoritehunters.blogspot.com/

As a follow up to the post below about the balloon coordinates  check out this image! http://www.flickr.com/photos/nasamarshall/7101296287/in/photostream

An update on the balloon cam. "The payload includes the NASA low-light video camera  two GPS trackers  two Hero2 GoPro Cameras and a cryogenic thermometer. We are receiving GPS data from the payload. The balloon is currently ascending over the Sierra Nevada range near Bishop  CA. Launched at 11:53 p.m. PDT. "Coordinates as of 12:09 am. PDT: Latitude=37.31692  Longitude=-118.59526"
Ground track for the meteor described in "A brilliant start to the Lyrids!"
The NASA camera at New Mexico State University captured this -3 magnitude Lyrid as it cut an arc across the sky at 2:26 AM local time.

The NASA fireball cameras in New Mexico picked up our first 3 Lyrids last night! They had peak magnitudes of -1.5  -3  and -3 (Mars/Jupiter brightness)  and burned up between 83 and 91 km altitude (51.6 and 56.6 miles in U.S. units); average speed was 46.3 km/sec  or 103 600 mph. You can easily identify the 3 Lyrids in this orbit plot by the similarity of their orbits.

We're receiving a signal from #LightSail! The first packets of data have been decoded! #Onward sail.planetary.org
Liftoff! #LightSail is on its way to space following a successful launch this morning.
#LightSail is at the launch pad! Take a look at pictures from the roll out this morning.
Two more days until #LightSail launches into orbit!
Join us on the adventure of space exploration. Send your #SelfieToSpace on #LightSail in 2016. planetary.org/selfie
Are you ready to fly through space aboard #LightSail? Submit your #SelfieToSpace to ride on the LightSail mission in 2016. planetary.org/selfie
What's it like to watch a sunset on Mars?
It's the best photo of our moon you'll see all day.

In 1976  Carl Sagan appeared on The Tonight Show to talk about a crazy new idea: solar sailing. Nearly 40 years later  The Planetary Society is realizing this dream with a new spacecraft called LightSail designed to propel through space on beams of sunlight.  sail.planetary.org Carson Footage Supplied Courtesy of Carson Entertainment Group Music by General Fuzz
So long MESSENGER  and thanks for all the photos!

Protecting Our Planet from Near-Earth Objects   http://bit.ly/1DHvcbt  We’re crowdfunding the detection of potentially dangerous asteroids and comets. If you are serious about protecting the planet  make sure you support our Shoemaker NEO Grant Program on Global Giving.

Embarking on its first test flight in May 2015  #LightSail will perform critical function tests in preparation for its 2016 flight to demonstrate the viability of solar sailing for CubeSats (tiny  low-cost satellites). LightSail is completely funded by private citizens like you.  (Music by General Fuzz -  generalfuzz.com)

Chang'e 5 T1 rounds the lunar farside  returns lovely photo of Earth and the Moon together  http://bit.ly/132zPyt  The Chang'e 5 test vehicle's short mission is more than half over. It has rounded the far side of the Moon and is on its way back to Earth for a planned October 31 test of lunar sample return technology. It's not a science mission -- it's an engineering mission -- but it has managed to return an absolutely iconic photo of its distant home  seen across the very unfamiliar far side of the Moon.
Credit: ESO/S. Brunier
Congratulations to Cosmos for winning 4 Emmy awards this year! Did you know host Neil deGrasse Tyson serves on The Planetary Society Board of Directors?

We're at the comet! http://bit.ly/1ocxTfg  After a journey of more than a decade  Rosetta has finally arrived at comet 67P Churyumov-Gerasimenko. Confirmation of the successful rocket firing came at about 9:30 UTC via a webcast from ESA's Operations Centre in Darmstadt  Germany.

Hubble to the rescue! The last-ditch effort to discover a Kuiper belt target for New Horizons  More here: http://bit.ly/1pdH3Xr  Will New Horizons have a mission after Pluto? Ground-based searches have failed to turn up anything that New Horizons can reach. Now Hubble is joining the search  but time is running out: a discovery must be made within the next two months.  (Image: New Horizons KBO search team)

Can't get enough pretty pictures of the cosmos? Award-winning astrophotographer Adam Block shares some of his recent work.  More here: http://bit.ly/1olqwjN  (Image: Adam Block / Mount Lemmon SkyCenter / University of Arizona)

Mars Exploration Rovers Update: Opportunity Hunts Ancient Clays along Murray Ridge  More here: http://bit.ly/1i71oHT  At the western rim of Endeavour Crater  Opportunity spent the month of May exploring a new clayground along Murray Ridge and the Mars Exploration Rovers (MER) mission trundled into the 125th month of what was originally to be a short  3-month tour.  (Image: NASA / JPL-Caltech / Cornell / ASU)

There are places in the American West where you can still see the tracks carved by pioneer wagon wheels more than a century ago. Pioneer trails extend all the way to Mars. Bill Dunford shows us these tracks in the wilderness.  More images and info: http://bit.ly/1h5Z09c  (Image: NASA / JPL / Cornell)

After a multi-day floor debate  the House of Representatives passed its Commerce-Justice-Science funding bill  which included a NASA budget $435 million above the President's 2015 request and an increase to planetary science.  It's now the Senate's turn to act  but this is a great first step.  More here: http://bit.ly/1nLhUTn

The House revealed details of its draft NASA budget today  including an increase of $170 million to Planetary Science above the White House's request for 2015  putting it within spitting distance of our goal of $1.5 billion.  More here: http://bit.ly/1s49xRZ

The House Proposes an Extra $435 million for NASA next year.  Budget season is in full swing in Washington  D.C.  and we're starting to see indications of how NASA will fare this year. I have to say  things are looking pretty promising.  More here: http://bit.ly/1umW3o5  (Image: Navid Baraty)

Pictures like this (from NASA's New Horizons spacecraft as it flew by Jupiter) are just one of the reasons we fight so hard to #FundPlanetary exploration. Join us and write to Congress: http://support.planetary.org/site/Advocacy?pagename=homepage&page=UserAction&id=173  Image Credit: NASA/APL/SwRI/GSFC

NASA announced today that their Europa mission concept studies will be for a sub-$1 billion spacecraft  a lower level than previously imagined for a mission to this watery moon.  More here: http://bit.ly/1hM7hg3  (Image: NASA / JPL / Daniel Machácek)

A few days ago  Curiosity looked westward after sunset and photographed Earth setting toward the mountainous rim of Gale crater. Look again at that dot. That's here. That's home. That's us.  More here: http://bit.ly/1bwawWj  (Image: NASA / JPL / MSSS / James Sorenson)
A group of hardworking JPLers celebrating #WomenInSTEM in our Space Flight Operations Facility.   More: http://go.nasa.gov/20Ys0CF

Congratulations to Opportunity and the Mars Exploration Rovers team! Still at the science grind  12 years into a 90-day mission. Info: http://go.nasa.gov/1PNUdEo

No joke—Voyager 2 flew by Uranus 30 years ago this Sunday. The 5.5-hour encounter revealed 10 new moons  a strange magnetic field and evidence of a boiling ocean about 500 miles (800 kilometers) below the cloud tops.   More: http://go.nasa.gov/1WC8Dge

Planet 9 from Outer Space: California Institute of Technology - Caltech scientists find evidence for another planet in our solar system. Details: http://www.caltech.edu/news/caltech-researchers-find-evidence-real-ninth-planet-49523

Five decades of successful NASA robotic missions to Mars have laid the groundwork for future human exploration of the Red Planet. #JourneyToMars
Since 1977  our Voyager spacecraft have carried the "Sounds of Earth" on their Golden Records. Now  you can listen via NASA's SoundCloud.

Sit back  relax and enjoy your flight over dwarf planet Ceres. The  flyover video was created from images of the heavily cratered and mysterious world taken by NASA's Dawn spacecraft during its first mapping orbit.

Saturn's moon #Enceladus may have hydrothermal activity. It's the first evidence found of such present-day activity beyond Earth.  News from NASA's Cassini Mission to Saturn: http://go.nasa.gov/1Ec5LOy
Brave New World: The NASA Dawn Mission is in orbit around #Ceres — first-ever spacecraft arrival at a dwarf planet. http://1.usa.gov/1A3NAXu

To our fellow Earthlings on the "Pale Blue Dot " here's a valentine courtesy the Voyager 1 spacecraft. Our interstellar ambassador turned around to take this image of our planet 25 years ago today. More info: http://go.nasa.gov/1vrTaRo

Providing closure. The UK-led Beagle 2 lander  lost during landing on Dec. 25  2003  has been located in images from the HiRISE camera on NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter.

The safe January 26 flyby of 2004 BL86 will be the closest by any known asteroid this large till 2027. http://go.nasa.gov/1xY3KE2   The asteroid is expected to be observable to amateur astronomers with small telescopes and strong binoculars.
NASA’s Curiosity Mars Rover team is dropping science at #AGU14. Their findings: -First organics detected on the surface of Mars -A 10x spike of atmospheric methane
Hear interstellar space "sing" for the third time. The latest plasma wave detected by the Voyager 1 spacecraft has been going on since February. More info: http://go.nasa.gov/137w0Yf

One gnarly-looking comet  one fantastic science destination! Congratuations to ESA - European Space Agency and the Rosetta Mission now in orbit around #67P!  Carrying three NASA instruments  Rosetta will now accompany and study the comet as it makes its way to the inner solar system. More info on the mission at:  http://1.usa.gov/XEBXtD
New chapter for NASA's NuSTAR space telescope: Two more years of science for the black-hole hunter. http://go.nasa.gov/1n8oL5a
Keep on trackin'! NASA's 10-year-old Aura satellite continues to study Earth's atmosphere. http://go.nasa.gov/1u0RBO9

Crash into Me: 20 years ago  we watched as comet Shoemaker-Levy 9 slammed into Jupiter. Full story:  http://go.nasa.gov/Wg5v0m  The event helped lead to the founding of NASA's Near-Earth Object Program Office  which finds  tracks and characterizes asteroids and comets that could approach Earth.
Heavy Metal: NASA’s Curiosity Mars Rover found an iron meteorite on Mars. http://go.nasa.gov/1rortIK  Note: This a composite image. The ChemCam pics are outlined.
Mission milestone! NASA's Cassini Mission to Saturn celebrates a decade of exploring the planet  its rings and moons.   http://go.nasa.gov/VAnC0L #Cassini10
What a long  strange trip (around the sun) it's been. See what the first Martian year held for NASA’s Curiosity Mars Rover: http://youtu.be/SSf1HenQhWs
Making science fiction a reality: NASA selects 12 advanced tech concepts for study  including 3 from JPL. Full story: http://go.nasa.gov/1jXtvZL
That's heavy. NASA's Kepler Mission discovers a planet 17 times as massive and twice the size of Earth: http://go.nasa.gov/1pBcSuK
Eyeing Storms from Air & Space: NASA launches 2014 campaign to probe hurricanes and tropical storms with unmanned aircraft and space-based missions. http://go.nasa.gov/1kl4Lur #EarthRightNow
Balloon + rocket + inflatable flying saucer + world's biggest supersonic parachute = LDSD. NASA preps to test new tech: http://go.nasa.gov/1k9BIOO

First Earth-size planet in the "habitable zone" discovered by NASA's Kepler Mission. Details: http://go.nasa.gov/1itJMsQ

Was "Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy" right? NASA research indicates element 42  molybdenum  and processes at undersea vents may be an answer to life and how it arose on Earth. Full story: http://go.nasa.gov/1evuT9K
Curiouser & Curiouser! NASA’s Curiosity Mars Rover is rolling up on her next science waypoint for a closer look at these odd rocks. Mission update: http://go.nasa.gov/OSBU8S
